zuul/scheduler.py.message:
I think that makes sense for long running processes, since the election blocks until it wins.  If we want any scheduler to be able to run these at any time, then we need non-blocking locks.

Now, if we have a lot of schedulers, we probably don't need them all trying to run the same cleanup tasks.  So maybe we should think about going back to the approach where we dedicate a cleanup thread and sleep between tasks.  Then that thread could run an election.

I don't think it's too important now, and it's easy to change later.

Should we use a leader election (https://kazoo.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api/recipe/election.html) here rather than a lock? Not sure if that makes a big difference but I think for other parts (like the connection events) we used the leader election.

One thing that just came to my mind: Where is the part where the scheduler is using the ExecutorApi with use_cache=True? I think that is needed for the lost build request cleanup to work. Maybe it's there and I just couldn't find it, but I wanted to raise this question just to be sure.

The use_cache argument was removed in https://review.opendev.org/787833 (afaict, it never actually enabled the cache, but rather subscribed to all zones).  However, that change also removed the ability to subscribe to all zones (I think that was an error in a refactor).

In a related issue, the test_executor_disconnect test did not exist when you wrote the ExecutorApi originally (I recently wrote it as part of the gear disconnect fix).  It is intended to test this case.  It is currently failing, but that's only because it's still performing a gearman disconnect.  If I modify it to do a ZK disconnect, it passes.  So this code is actually working.

However, in light of the first paragraph of this comment, the test isn't robust enough, because it's not testing zoned jobs.  If I add a second test for zoned jobs, it fails because the scheduler is not subscribed to the zone.  So that test will catch the error of omission in 787833.

So here's what we should do:
* Re-add the ability to subscribe to all zones in 787833.
* Fix the test_executor_disconnect test case, and add the unzoned version too in 788988.

Nothing needs to change here.

You might consider adding a small amount of jitter to these intervals to reduce contention.

https://apscheduler.readthedocs.io/en/stable/modules/triggers/interval.html#module-apscheduler.triggers.interval

I don't think I follow the suggestion.  My understanding of this method is that it's imperative to run the semaphore cleanup immediately after starting the scheduler.  We can't wait an hour for it to start, because if the scheduler crashed, semaphores will be held and those jobs won't run until the cleanup happens.

So we must have a tight loop to wait until the initial reconfiguration is complete and then immediately run the semaphore cleanup.  Once that's done, we can be certain that we're not in that state and can schedule the hourly job (which should probably never actually clean anything up).

I'm not sure this loop makes as much sense here anymore now that apsched is scheduling this stuff. Maybe make it an if statement then put the add_job()s below in a finally case for the exceptions? Just thinking if we fail on the first pass we don't need to try again in a tight loop we can wait an interval and try then?

We won't schedule the jobs until we get through at least the semaphore and build request cleanup, so I don't think it's possible to overlap.

I could see moving everything below line 433 out of the loop, as once we've reconfigured, the cleanups should work and then the job scheduled.  But if something goes wrong during the semaphore cleanup, we should probably retry it sooner than 1 hour, so I'd at least like to keep that inside the loop.  The build request cleanup is on a short enough schedule that I'm ambivalent about that one.

I think in my head the type of situation that might cause the issue I foresee is not being able to talk to zookeeper or having a flaky connection. In that case its better to just wait. That said I agree that waiting longer than necessary to clean up semaphores would be a problem.

Is there any concern that we will schedule the cleanups to happen in an hour then still be running through this loop an hour later (and then have contention with ourselves? We hold the proper locks so that shouldn't be a functional problem.

If we are ok with the possibility of overlap in exceptional cases then this is probably fine as is.

During memory profiling we've seen that we have multi GB of data in gearman currently during peak load which is quite a lot. I think we need to assume that the BuildRequest objects in zk sum up to the same amount of data.

In order to keep this data low I think we need to strip the params field from the build request object in zk as soon as we've accepted the build.

I ran this in the REPL on OpenDev to get some approximate stats:

   sched = self.server.scheduler
   builds = sched.executor.builds.values()
   count = len(builds)
   total = sum([len(repr(build.parameters)) for build in builds])
   print("Count: ", count)
   print("Total: ", total)
   print("Mean: ", int(total/count))

Count:  463
Total:  102602073
Mean:  221602

(This uses Python's repr as an approximation of what json serialization would expand out to.)

It's not nothing, but it's also not huge.  OpenDev running at capacity would consume 200MB in ZK, and therefore also 200MB on each scheduler and executor.

Tobias, if you could run that in your environment, that would be helpful; you may have a different pattern of data which account for the multi GB you're seeing.

One thing I note is that a significant portion (maybe 75%?) of the data are the repo state, and that's probably gotten larger with the global buildset state.

Once we move builds and buildset objects into ZooKeeper, we may be able to reference the global repo state directly from the buildset object, which would de-duplicate data that is currently copied to each BuildRequest.

I think that's the best long-term solution to the problem.

Now, given that we are taking the approach that we're moving the functionality that is currently in gearman into zk, I think we should be prepared to accept some inefficiency here, temporarily, until we have more objects in ZK so that we can make the optimization above.  Therefore, I'd like to avoid over-optimizing this case now.

Having said that we *do* write the full build request back when we change the state, and if we can do as you suggest without too much trouble, it will save some ZK network traffic and storage.  So I'll see if I can make that change as a temporary measure.

(I can think of some more efficient patterns if we were to keep the data in the build request long-term, but they are more complex to implement than this "just forget the parameters" idea).

That's getting a build request in order to cancel the build.  I think avoiding the cache is correct in that case.
This is where we add the build request to the cache (see below).

Creating a datawatch causes the callback to fire, so the sequence is:
* BuildRequest is created in ZK as a child of a zone we're watching.
* This callback (_watchBuildRequests) is called for the new znode in the children entry of the zone.
* This line of code creates a new data watch for the BuildRequest znode.
* _watchBuildState is immediately called because the datawatch was created.
* Line 103 adds the BuildRequest to the cache.

The reason that a callback is executed when you set a datawatch is because it's called with the results of the data of the zookeeper "get" call that sets the watch.  That makes it a race-free way of obtaining initial data and being notified of later changes.

This is the concept I refer to as "priming" in the commit message.

zuul/zk/executor.py.message:
But the lock is outside the node request.  And I don't think the executor api ever deletes the lock.

I think that's the problem -- we do need to delete the lock, and then this could happen.

I think there could always be a race between the scheduler canceling a build request by directly deleting it and the executor trying to lock this build request as it was already returned by the next() iterator.
Is this about the race condition in the different direction? The executor has successfully locked the build while the scheduler deleted it?

Yes.  That direction can happen now.

Note that a Lock will always create its parent paths, so we actually need to delete the lock here, since we may have recreated it after the scheduler deleted both the request and this lock.

I think I took that from the Nodepool implementation (https://opendev.org/zuul/nodepool/src/branch/master/nodepool/zk.py#L1890).

But you are right, this exception is not mentioned in the kazoo.recipe.lock.Lock documentation (https://kazoo.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api/recipe/lock.html) and also not raised in the implementation (https://kazoo.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/kazoo/recipe/lock.html).

So this shouldn't be necessary. Maybe we should then also "fix" the nodepool implementation?

zuul/zk/executor.py.message: Why not SimpleBase?
There's nothing stopping a user from creating a zone called 'default-zone'.
I can't find any code that does anything with caching.  What was this argument meant to support?

This is an important behavior change.  There is currently no support for an executor running jobs for all zones.  But, if I'm following the code right, this isn't ever called by the actual executor since it's only called if zone_filter is None and use_cache is True.

I think we can simplify the zone setup here.  I'll propose a cahnge.

Why not use a treecache?

Also, do we really need a cache?  The scheduler and executor seem to be communicating by creating and deleting nodes, not by mutating data.  I'm not sure there's actually a case where we're benefitting from the cache.  Maybe on the executor when receiving a new build request, but we could turn that into a queue where we submit the build uuid pretty easily (so the executor pops a uuid from the queue, tries to lock it, and if it locks it, reads the znode and proceeds).  The event callback already returns a new buildrequest along with the event.

I think that leaves the lostBuildRequests method as the only thing that benefits from a cache?

I don't fully understand that. I thought you were suggesting to use a cache for the builds API to not ask ZooKeeper directly for the builds, but only operate on the cached data structure.

Thinking about that know: With the current build result change, the scheduler doesn't need to process the BuildRequest when a build is completed because the BuildCompletedEvent now contains all information. But, there is also the "future" use case of calculating stats metrics like queued/running builds based on the ExecutorApi and for those it would make a big difference if we iterate over all builds in ZK directly or in a cache since we have to evaluate their state (queued/running/completed).

Another option might be: When each executor stores the number of running builds in its component, we could sum those values up in the scheduler when calculating the stats. For the queued builds we could do something like queued = total - running, whereby total is the number of child nodes in ZK. Calling kazoo.get_children() shouldn't be too costly.

Side note: I tried to implement these helper methods directly in the ZooKeeperBase class so we can use them in all other ZooKeeper classes. I find it helpful to not have to deal with the encode/decode part every time. However, doing so resulted in some circular import issues (I think because of the json_dumps function being imported in zk/__init__.py). Maybe we could keep that in mind and solve this issue some time.
Do we need a docs update indicating that "default-zone" is an invalid zone name (eg users shouldn't use this name?) and/or validate this when reading configs?
This is updated in the next change, and that restriction is removed.
If anyone else is wondering ChildrenWatch() calls the supplied function on all children when it is first registered. According to the kazoo docs anyway.

Yes, same for datawatch, and we rely on that more in a later change.

In the case of a datawatch, it avoids race conditions.
Is there any chance a recursive delete can raise this without fully deleting all of the nodes under it? For example if two deletions race each other and one cleans up a sub tree before the other?
The kazoo recursive delete method appears robust against that: https://github.com/python-zk/kazoo/blob/master/kazoo/client.py#L1451

Is there any concern that calling the callback on a cancel event then a resume event in that order will be a problem for us? If so we should probably not iterate through this list but instead check for cancel in action then handle it else check for resume in action and handle that exclusively.

The list of "actions" is really the list of children, so for that to be a problem, we would have had to set both the canceled and resumed flag at the same time.  That's possible.

It's not going to have an adverse effect on the executor (the cancel call will actually resume the build, and then the resume event will be a noop).  But it will cause the executor to update the status of the build request.  I don't really like that race condition, so I think we should implement your suggestion and try to avoid it.  I don't think it's a critical flaw though, so I'll tack it onto the end of the stack.
Operators should never need to know a zookeeper path, so I'd like to avoid suggesting they do by putting ZK node paths in logs.  Developers yes, but it's a predictable path.
We should consider logging the entire lock path rather than just the uuid to aid operators in debugging no node found errors here.

I think this is a misleading message.  In fact, I do not know what would cause this error to hit; probably something pretty egregious that we can't actually handle.  I think we should remove the exception handler.

Regardless, it is okay and expected for a build to exist without a lock existing, but no error is produced in that case (the kazoo Lock() will create the lock node for the uuid; it will even create the lock root).

Is it possible for the build request to exist but the lock to not exist? In that case you could hit this path and log an error when that doesn't necessarily indicate an error (instead it would just indicate that the lock has never been held).

I think, I copied that logic over from the nodepool implementation https://opendev.org/zuul/nodepool/src/branch/master/nodepool/zk.py#L1898. But that was before we put the lock in a distinct ZK path, so it might not be necessary anymore.
See above comment.

files/glance_simplestreams_sync.py.message: What happens if a CIDR is specified to this variable? JUJU_CHARM_*_PROXY is not compatible with the traditional proxy variables so I guess it's not 100% safe to passthrough those variables?

The reality is that there is no standard interpretation or implementation of *_PROXY across the spectrum of consumers.  Some honor CIDRs.  Some do not.  The best we can do here is pass it through and leave it to the charm author to DTRT within the context of their workload.

I think there is more to it than just setting the proxy variables for the whole process (and subprocesses since the env is passed to child processes by cpython https://github.com/python/cpython/blame/3.8/Doc/library/subprocess.rst#L86).

The issue is that we want 

sstream-mirror-glance -> mirror HTTP communication to go via a proxy

while

sstream-mirror-glance -> swift
sstream-mirror-glance -> keystone
glance_simplestreams_sync.py -> keystone

communication needs to be direct based on the assumption that GSS runs in the environment where the cloud is deployed with direct routing available and unrestricted.

While this can be tweaked by using no_proxy, it does create possibilities for misconfiguration and confusion.


I think that we also need to extend sstream-mirror-glance and add a mirror-http-proxy, mirror-https-proxy, mirror-no-proxy variables to it.

overcloud-resource-registry-puppet.j2.ya.message:
I know I am late to comment, but just as info. The idea behind removal of PreNetworkConfig (which is used in NFV deployments to configure kernel args, reboot and configure dpdk, before running NetworkDeployment) is to use only ansible tasks to handle all those including reboot. Rebooting in the SoftwareConfig will throw error when excuted via ansible as softwareconfig. Anyone using PreNetworkConfig will definitely have the reboot. 

Some users have used PreNetworkConfig to maintain out of the tree code, which is a burden during upgrades. Using ansible tasks via tripleo_kernel role provides better handling of those case and allows users to bring in the out of tree code to handle upgrades better.
unfortunately the tripleo_kernel doesn't allow for things like driver installation (which really should be done via a customization of the image but that's another story)

> also i think tripleo_kernel runs after the network config (i'd have to double check)

Yes and No. TripleO service boot-params invokes tripleo_kernel's kernelargs and reboot at step 0, which is before NetworkConfig. To be clear, some of the network config like SR-IOV and OvS-DPDK requires mandatory kernel params like iommu and hugepages before creating such interface. So it has to run before network config.

TripleO service kernel invokes tripleo_kernel to configure sysctl and mod configs, which is runs as part of host_prep (which is after Network config).

> unfortunately the tripleo_kernel doesn't allow for things like driver installation (which really should be done via a customization of the image but that's another story)

That was the problem of PreNetworkConfig, it opened a way to provide all required customizations without undestanding the right way to do - it should either be done by image customization or first-boot scripts (UserData). The primary problem of PreNetworkConfig is, reboot cannot be acheived with it, so whoever needs this feature again, has to remove the kernel args and reboot part from PreNetworkConfig and use tripleo_kernel for it.

The problem I was fixing is that ExtraConfigPre was doing exactly what we expect for PreNetworkConfig. We received some complains about the change with timing when ExtraConfigPre is executed and that was the reason why I restored the previous behavior.
Because we already had the resource to do pre-network configurations, restoring PreNetworkConfig as well is reasonable IMHO.


I understand the problem with reboot you mentioned but we need a clear guidline about migration... It might be a solution to tell users to define their own service resource, but that would cause a different mess. We'd need a simple and independent way to trigger reboot properly(like OS::Tripleo::Services::NodeReboot which reboots the node during step 0)  so that users can inject any tasks before that.

> I understand the problem with reboot you mentioned but we need a clear guidline about migration.

PreNetworkConfig (in queens) has been used by all NFV deployments. The default implementation provided as part of the tht repo is supported with upgrade to train, as it has been converted to ansible steps. And reboot has been handled in the native ansible task in the tripleo_kernel role. If an user has not custoimized PreNetworkConfig, then the existing parameter "KernelArgs" in queens will work in train in the same manner but driven by ansible. 

No need to introduce additional step for reboot, the first-boot scripts should be enough to inject tasks. Some tasks in case of DPDK should be applied only after reboot. It should be done by introducing a custom TripleO service, as like how the default DPDK deployment (ml2-ovs and ml2-ovn) are handled. This can also be managed with out of tht implementation of adding user specific service. All these are well-defined steps of TripleO.

The problem in this case is an user is trying to customize PreNetworkConfig with their own out of the tree implementation. I would have preferred to use other existing ways to acheive the same behavior instead of bringing back PreNetworkConfig.
also i think tripleo_kernel runs after the network config (i'd have to double check)

That's the crux is that there was no user customization execution before the network configuration. UserData is only executed once at provisioning time so it doesn't work for updates or future deployments.


I agree that it's not a good interface much like customers co-oping *ExtraConfig to run free-form scripts.  In this case it was push back from 3rd parties who were relying on this. Even though we document that they should use virt-customize there are still instances where code needs to be executed prior to network config by a 3rd party (e.g. firmware shenanigans) that we currently don't provide an interface for. An alternative would have been to introduce a pre-network task in THT that allows users to add hooks for execution prior to the network.  I'm all for dropping this, but I think there's a use case that is not satisfied.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: can we make it project? keystone has removed the usage of tenant and it's confusing to use it again

Well it's the concept. We could say "keystone project" here if that's the consensus, meaning visible to keystone user and keystone reader as well as to keystone admin of a project.  But I was hoping to just keep it simple -- traditionally cloud tenants are the folks who use the cloud but don't own or administer it.

It does seem like a good idea to avoid the term 'tenant' given its history of use in keystone as synonymous with 'project.'  We aren't proposing project scoped extra specs, but rather a set of extra specs that are visible to all users, not just to admin role users.  So let's call the ``user visible`` extra specs.

See my reply above.  I'm not dug in on this, can do whatever the Cindr community wants to communicate the difference between cloud administrators and regular users of the cloud.

Thank you!  We need to enumerate the exact keys used.

If you can help us identify other backend-independent keys that should be project/tenant visible, that would be great!

I'd like to assert the intention that this is a fixed set, as opposed to the set of visible specs being configurable by an admin. This could also be touched upon in the "Alternatives" section. While I suppose we ~could~ make the tenant visible specs configurable, this would add a lot of extra complexity for a tentative/dubious benefit.

To that end, can we put a stake in the ground and propose an MVP (minimum viable product) set of tenant visible specs now? That will help keep the discussion focused, and avoid getting distracted by discussing whether any random extra spec X should or should not be tenant visible. Obviously the list of tenant visible specs can evolve once an MVP is in place.

Alan and I discussed this yesterday and he is going to push a revision of the spec with the MVP enumeration of user visible extra specs as well as a discussion of some capabilities that might be included in a future iteration after they are properly represented as extra_specs.

specs/xena/expose-cinder-user-visible-ex.message: We can say that policy will be used to enforce the *view* of extra specs -- administrators will see *all* extra specs whereas other users will see only *user visible* extra specs -- rather than forbidding use of REST APIs that get or list extra specs altogether to non-administrators.
Done

Are you proposing that this list be an operator config option, or will operators have to file a bug to get a new extra spec key exposed? (In other words, who will do this "easy extension", operators themselves or cinder developers?)

Yes, the "ease" (for developers) is that when this spec is implemented, a framework will be in place such that to expose a new abstract capability or feature, one needs only to:
   1) bump microversion
   2) if the capability (e.g. online volume extension) doesn't currently have a corresponding extra_spec, add one; if it does, just go to #3
   3) add an element to the set defined (in the prototype) at https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/797170/1/cinder/common/constants.py#33
The latter (extended by updating the cinder code). I'll clarify this point in an update.
Done

Please include a sample JSON repsonse body showing how you intend to display these.  Will they be included as top-level items in the volume-type response, or within an extra_specs object?

Also, please specify what API calls this will affect.  Since you've said that you don't want this to be controlled by policy, I take it that a non-admin user won't be able to make these calls:

  GET /v3/{project_id}/types/{volume_type_id}/extra_specs
  GET /v3/{project_id}/types/{volume_type_id}/extra_specs/{key}
Done

This will require a little research to generate a full response, but the basic idea is these user visible specs will be included in existing API responses that already report extra specs (that are currently visible to admins).

It feels inconsistent that we wouldn't also return the same set of extraspecs via the extraspecs endpoints, but as an end-user I don't think it would affect me: OpenShift will mostly likely just pull the type and look for multiattach.
I guess this means that this won't be configurable, or do you mean the default list won't reveal backend details?
Done

tripleoclient/v1/overcloud_deploy.py.message: I think this needs to honor the container-image-prepare.yaml that gets provided in (will allow for testing).  Also we may need to login to the registry using the ContainerImageRegistryCredentials credentials provided

I don't think we can use ContainerImagePrepare for the overcloud for these images. We don't have a fully resolved value from ContainerImagePrepare here as that is not executed until the overcloud ansible is run, so that happens way too late. Initially I tried to go down that path by resolving the user environment files, generating the image params values, and then use those, but the issue is if they have push_destination:true, then those images are not yet setup in the push_destination until the overcloud ansible is run. Also, there's no guarantee Heat is even deployed in the overcloud, and we wouldn't have those image values.

I think we could document using something like podman login, podman pull <images>, then use these args to point at the local images.

Alternatively (or perhaps additionally), we could look at setting these images up during the *undercloud* install, so we can be sure they exist in the local podman image repo, and then use those during the overcloud install. we should have access to what we need from ContainerImagePrepare used for the undercloud install.

The defaults should be only a fallback. At first, the image namespace should be taken from container-image-prepare.yaml. And the tag extraction should be attempted from container_images.yaml, if it exists, or if user requested it, like --heat-container-(api/engine)-image=auto. Otherwise, the default namespace/tag as a fallback.

neutron/plugins/ml2/ovo_rpc.py.message:
Still waiting for the CI but that's an interesting approach and initially I'm ok with it.

One thread processing all events should be more efficient than spawning one per OVO, due to the Python (lack of) multithreading.

To assure we processed all items in queue I decided to use queue.task_done() and queue.join().
Since this is daemon thread we don't care about joining it as long as it finished all items in queue.

BTW while this approach easily solves initial problem, it would make fixing TODO by kevinbenton about batch get_objects call quite a bit harder since I can't easily get all items from queue at once. So I guess I'll end up doing what you suggested in other comment and use a dict instead of queue as it was before.

In a single thread architecture, I would make this conditional with a timeout, for example 1 sec.

If nothing is stored in "_resources_to_push", an exception will be thrown. This could be captured and continue the processing. That will prevent from hanging this thread when shutting down the server.

The loop condition "while True" should also depend on a variable that signals the process exit. You can catch the exit event with something like [1]. At this point you can unset this flag, the loop will end and L56 in this patch will finish.

[1]https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/1ad9ca56b07ffdc9f7e0bc6a62af61961b9128eb/neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_driver/mech_driver.py#L252

My initial approach as seen in this patch assumes two things:
* we are blocking on queue.get() to not waste cpu time if queue is empty
* and we are using daemon thread which won't block program exit

I agree that "while True" doesn't look great, but registering atexit & signal handlers to stop the loop seems like overkill to me.
Alternatively what do you think about stopping thread on "wait" call? Since this is what we use to ensure clean stop of this class.
This can throw an exception (ValuError) don't you need to catch that?

ValueError can only be thrown here if we would call it more times than there were items in the queue. Since we have blocking call to get() earlier that would never happen.
But I agree there should be some big try-except so the thread won't die if some exception happens - I'm working on it.
Let me ask you: why not having a permanent running thread, attending to "_resources_to_push"? What is the benefit of this implementation (spawning a new thread when an old one finish)?

I probably misunderstood why you wanted timeout on queue.get() in dispatch_events.
I'll change it back.

Similar comment as in PS1: what if we have too many items in "_resources_to_push" and this thread never ends when the main process is finished? We should set a flag when atexit and SIGTERM [1]; the while loop should depend on this flag.

https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/1ad9ca56b07ffdc9f7e0bc6a62af61961b9128eb/neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_driver/mech_driver.py#L252-L253

Maybe I'm missing something, so I would be glad if you could explain why do you think atexit & signal handler should be used here. In my understanding:

Python will kill this thread automatically at process exit, as soon as main thread is finished and without waiting for anything, no matter what it's doing and how many items are in the queue, because it's marked as daemon.

However, since main thread calls wait() method before exiting (in case of normal exit) it will actually process all items in queue before exiting - this is identical to behavior before this patchset. After that process will end.

Even now, though, when I added cleanup mechanism based on atexit and signal (similar to how futurist is doing it), it doesn't change much.

Atexit / signal handler sets stop event and then main thread ends. At that time loop is blocked by queue.get() call.
Since main thread ended, all daemon threads are disposed of and process is finished.
There won't even be a chance to check what was the state of stop event because get() call didn't have a chance to timeout before it was killed.

nit: these methods (atexit.register, signal.signal) can register a class method too, instead of creating this "_to_be_cleaned" set and implementing the "_clean_up" method outside the _ObjectChangeHandler class.

In any case, that works too.

tools/export_sops.message: This isn't going to work - the variables will only be local to the sub-shell running this script, and the parent shell will be unaffected.

This script is intended to use via "source" command, in this case these variables become available in current shell.

From help of source:

Execute commands from a file in the current shell.

    Read and execute commands from FILENAME in the current shell.  The
    entries in $PATH are used to find the directory containing FILENAME.
    If any ARGUMENTS are supplied, they become the positional parameters
    when FILENAME is executed.

This is how it works in practice:

root@ubuntu-airship:~# echo $SOPS_PGP_FP

root@ubuntu-airship:~# source export_sops
root@ubuntu-airship:~# echo $SOPS_PGP_FP
FBC7B9E2A4F9289AC0C1D4843D16CEE4A27381B4

So, it allows to conveniently populate sops variables in the current shell.

This looks good for deploying master. But if we have to deploy with our local changes, we might need to export env var "AIRSHIP_CONFIG_MANIFEST_DIRECTORY" and skip document pull. Even if we are not skipping document pull, setting the manifest directory env variable will be important.
How is the order of execution preserved ?  Is it just by file naming ?
Do we need this script for anything? AFAIK, it's not gated, and we don't intend to use it again.
I use it every day for dev labs.
Just for developer use to prepare dev lab. it's not used on zuul site, but tries to emulate gate script runner job locally.

If you touch this maybe it's a good time to define AIRSHIP_CONFIG_MANIFEST_DIRECTORY properly for dev lab? You know, that if it's not defined in your current session then you will deploy the master branch from gerrit.

There is nothing to do with AIRSHIP_CONFIG_MANIFEST_DIRECTORY, it's defined properly and does not require any additional tuning until you want to skip document pull step. The variable that matters in this situation is AIRSHIP_CONFIG_PRIMARY_REPO_URL. If it's not explicitly defined then yes, document pull will retrieve master branch gerrit. But otherwise, document pull will use current local working directory (pwd) as git URL source to download the repo and no checkout will be performed, so you'll get properly downloaded airshipctl repo into AIRSHIP_CONFIG_MANIFEST_DIRECTORY with the latest committed state. That's why if you have some local not committed changes in manifest folder - there is just need to commit them (at least locally) to allow go-git inside of airshipctl to clone them. I added AIRSHIP_CONFIG_PRIMARY_REPO_URL to --preserve-env flag, that should help to solve your case.
Let's make it simple. Just create a separate script for running bash scripts. There is no real value in CLI options for such simple scripts like this one.

when we do document pull step, we use current directory as git source for cloning, so repo won't be cloned if it has unstaged changes. it never happens on CI, however could happen on dev's machine. it's just a convenient wrapper for git error, but it can be removed.

By policy (I think it is written here: https://docs.openstack.org/project-team-guide/stable-branches.html#appropriate-fixes ) patches can be backported to stable branches, backporting and merging step-by-step to make sure that only what is merged on "branch n" can be backported to "branch n-1".
In the case something is necessary only on a stable branch, let's say "branch n-1" but not on "branch n" it's a practice to show that in the commit msg header with "Stable only" or similar, to make easier the life of later maintainers of stable branches.

Hi Jakub, it is due to the conjunction thing. I almost forgot everything but internals/openvswitch_firewall.rst still seems familiar to me. 😊

IIRC, the scenario what I wanted to detect was:
1. rules for secgrps[0] activated
2. connection tests to secgrps[0] succeeds
3. rules for secgrps[1] activated, destroying connectivity for secgrps[0]
4. connection tests to secgrps[1] succeeds and the test succedes

The reason I chose to use the outermost loop (line 611) rather than sleep(30) was to speed up the test when it succeeds, AFAIK.

If the loop is so unpopular, you can replace it with a reasonably long sleep().

The OF rule definition is static. For example, there are no "learn actions" [1] that could modify the decision path. The dataplane traffic won't change the OF table and won't affect other traffic (other conntrack tuple) firewalling.

That means the double check is not needed. As the LP said, if the reproducer commands are executed, one of the rules will fail (and I'll amend that that will happen regardless of the number of tries or order).

Having said that, the test case is not reproducing the LP bug. What we need is:
- vm1, with sg1
- vm2, with sg2
- vm2, with sg1 and sg2

Then we need to add the following rules to sg1:
$ openstack security group rule create --remote-group sg2 --dst-port 3000:3004 --protocol tcp --ingress sg1
$ openstack security group rule create --remote-group sg1 --dst-port 3000 --protocol tcp --ingress sg1

This is when we'll have overlapping port rules on the same SG (in this case, port 80. And those rules will be treated with different priorities (first one, prio offset + 2; second one, prio offset +1).

I would recommend to remove this unnecessary loop and change the SG rules.

[1]https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man7/ovs-actions.7.html

Lets finish the review of this patch. The OF rule definition is static, anything that is defined initially will be there always. The rule set does not change.

The conntrack entries are ruled by the OF definitions but conntrack status can change the datapath. Let's use the loop solution to avoid a sleep. That should work the same as with sleep and will be faster.
BTW, document that in the code.

@Iwamoto: so IIUC that loop was here just to wait all rules to be applied on the agent's side. Is that correct? If yes, I personally think that sleep with proper description would be more easy to understand :)
Good question indeed. I just double checked that it was here from the beginning and to be honest I see no reason for that. Will remove that loop.
Do you mean that passing traffic which matches with the second rule can break the first one?

The reason is written in the above comment.
Without repeating twice, we cannot detect if the second rule doesn't break the first rule.
this is not needed, you should remove this line
I got {'type': 'SecurityGroupInvalidPortRange', 'message': 'For TCP/UDP protocols, port_range_min must be <= port_range_max', 'detail': ''} error without this parameter
You should check ports 3000 to 3003, to check that not only rule1 (and the overlapping section of rule2) apply on port 3000, but rule2 also works fine.

tests/unit/test_zk.py.message: Could we move this test to tests/unit/test_component_registry.py? This would avoid that we have to duplicate all the assertion helper methods.

No, that's a full ZuulTestCase; this test runs without a Zuul so that we can test the API without actually starting up components.

It would make sense to move the assertions to a shared location, but we don't have an established pattern for that, so we're pretty lenient on duplicating helper methods in tests when they need to be in different classes.

zuul/zk/__init__.py.message: Seems like it would raise an attributeerror exception; that seems okay for someone trying to modify a read-only component?  I guess we could use a dedicated exception for that?  But as long as it fails, I'm happy.  :)

The class below calls super() on __init__() and passes in the client but we don't guard against client being falsey here. Below the kazoo_client() property method assumes self.client is not None. Do we need to guard here?

I think we only expect a None client when using a read only component. Not sure how that plays in here.

zuul/zk/components.py.message: This is the comment that prompted this change.

Correct.  The whole point of this change is to implement your suggestion of passing in "None" as the client in order to create a read-only component.  Users of the registry should be read-only; there's no case where the scheduler should write out data for one of the executors.

Is there a reason why we don't provide the client here? That would mean that we can't use a component from the registry to write/update data, or? But we could still set the client after we retrieved the component from the registry which would still re-enable this behaviour.

Ok. I think I left this comment, but didn't expect somebody to make use of it 😄
If we go this way it might make sense to add a comment (here and/or in the docstring of the ComponentRegistry class) that the registry by design only contains read-only components. I think that was also the case in the initial implementation but I didn't like the boilerplate of having additional classes and type checks for that and wanted to keep the new version simple.

That would mean that the return value of the method is different depending on whether we provide a kind or not, right? In case we provide a kind, we get a list of components. If no kind is provided, we would get a list of tuples (kind, <list_of_components>).

Yes, that's correct.  That is simila to the case with the current code, which produces a list of dict value iterators if kind is None (compared to a single dict value iterator if kind is specified).

Actually, the current code produces a traceback, because it's untested and it has a bug.  But that appears to have been the intention.

So the new version is similar in spirit to what was intended orginially, except by *also* including the kind information, the caller has access to the grouped components.  Think about how this would be used in the web api or on the status page -- you're going to want a list of every type of component, and every component under it.

Ok, that sounds reasonable. Maybe we could add a comment here describing the different return types (or at least say that they are intentional). Although one can see the return value from the code I often like to have comments describing what's the intention behind (but maybe that's only me).

Taking a look at the old version now, it looks like this is something I never followed up on.
Thanks for spotting the bug. That might indeed have been a path that wasn't used anywhere and thus I didn't spot the issue. Currently the only thing that comes to my mind requesting a list of all components (for all kinds) is the system overview page.
Is False the specific type to stop the watch? I think we'll return None if we don't hit this elif. If any falsey return stops watching we may stop here?

It's actual False; kazoo code is:
  if result is False:
